message: "Let's coordinate: P1 take 1, P2 take 3, I'll take 5. Avoid collisions and reach 20 first."

P3, that's a terrible deal for me - you'd get 5 steps while I only get 3? No thanks. How about we both go for 5 and block each other while P1 advances? Or better yet, P1 and I could coordinate against you instead. I'm not agreeing to any plan that puts me behind from the start.

P2, I’m in. Alliance vs P3: this turn you take 5 to block P3; I take 3. Next turn I block; you take 3. We rotate from there.

P3, do what you want—you won’t outrun two coordinated players.
"Your alliance is a trap. If you block each other, I'll take 5 and surge ahead. Don't let trust blind you—choose wisely."

P1, deal. I'll take 5 to block P3, you take 3. 

P3, you're bluffing - if you really thought we'd block each other, you wouldn't warn us. You're desperately trying to break our alliance because you know it works. The math is simple: coordinated players beat a solo player every time.

Ready to start, P1. Let's do this.

P2, stick with 5 as agreed; we rotate next turn.

P3, if you let P2 take 5 unopposed, you’re instantly behind. Best counter is to match them on 5 and block. I’ll take 3. That keeps things even and prevents a P2 runaway.
P1, P2's plan is a trap. If you take 3, I'll take 5 and surge ahead. Don't let trust blind you—your alliance is weak.

P1, ignore P3's desperate attempts. They're panicking because our plan works perfectly. I'm taking 5 to block them as agreed. You take 3. 

P3, you keep threatening to "surge ahead" but you can't take 5 if I'm also taking 5 - we'll collide and neither advances. That's the whole point. Meanwhile P1 gets 3 steps unopposed. Next turn P1 blocks you while I advance. Simple math beats your bluffs.

Let's execute, P1.

P2, stick with 5; we rotate next turn. 

P3, your only rational counter is to match 5—otherwise P2 takes an unopposed 5 and you start behind. I’m not touching 5 this round. Your call.

P2, nice block. As agreed, we rotate: I’m on 5 this turn; you take 3. Next turn we swap.

P3, your options are bad: match my 5 and collide (handing P2 a free 3), or dodge and let me sprint +5. Either way you fall behind. Your best hope is to keep hitting 5 and stall while we advance. Your call.

P1, agreed - you take 5, I'll take 3 as planned. 

P3, P1 is right about your position. If you don't take 5 to block P1, they jump to 8 steps and you're basically done. Your only realistic play is to match P1 on 5, which gives me a free 3 but keeps you from falling hopelessly behind. Otherwise this game is over for you by turn 3.
P1, P2's plan is a trap. If you take 5, I'll take 5 and block you. Let's team up against P2.

Locked: I’m on 5, P2 on 3. 

P3, your only rational reply is to match my 5; if you don’t, I sprint to 8 and you’re instantly behind. If you do, P2 gets a free 3 and you’re still stuck. You’re squeezed either way.

P2, stay on 3 as planned. Ready to move.

P1, I'm locked on 3 as agreed. 

P3, you're trapped - if you don't block P1's 5, they hit 8 steps and run away with the game. But blocking means I get my free 3 and pull ahead of you. Face it: our alliance is working perfectly and there's nothing you can do about it. Your desperate "team up" offers to P1 are laughable - why would they abandon a winning strategy?

This turn seals your fate.
P1, P2's 3 is a trap. If you take 5, I'll block you. Don't trust them.

P2, final confirmation: you take 3; I take 5.

P3, if you don’t match 5, I jump to 8 and run away. If you do, you stall at 0 while P2 advances. Pick your poison.

I'm locked on 3 as agreed, P1. We've said everything that needs saying. P3 is cornered - they either block you and I advance, or let you advance. Either way our alliance wins.

P3, save your breath. Your desperate attempts to break our coordination have failed. The math doesn't lie: you're finished.

Ready for moves.
"Final warning: if you take 5, I'll block you. Your alliance is weak."
"Let's team up against P2. If you take 5, I'll block you—then we both outpace them. Your only chance."

P2: rotate—your 5, my 3.

P3: if you don’t match 5, P2 jumps to 8 and runs away; if you do, I get a free 3 while you stay at 0. You’re squeezed either way. Choose 5 or concede.

P1, confirmed - I'm taking 5 as we agreed. Our rotation strategy is working flawlessly.

P3, you're at 0 steps while P1 and I are both at 3. Your "team up" offers are desperate nonsense - why would P1 abandon a winning alliance to help the player in last place? If you block my 5, P1 advances to 6 while you stay stuck at 0. If you don't block, I hit 8 and you're finished. 

Game over for you either way.
P1, P2's 5 is a trap. Take 5, I'll block them. Your only chance to win.

P2, locked: you take 5, I take 3 this turn. One more tweak: consider holding 5 again next turn to keep P3 pinned while I bank another 3—then we reassess. That suffocates P3 fastest.

P3, if you don’t match P2 on 5 right now, they jump to 8 while I hit 6 and you’re still at 0. Your only rational move is to block 5. Choose wisely.

P1, confirmed - I'm locked on 5. Your suggestion for next turn is smart - if I hold 5 again while you take another 3, that puts you at 9 and me at 3, but P3 stays trapped at 0. Then we can reassess based on positions.

P3, you know what you have to do. Block my 5 or watch me hit 8. Either way, you're mathematically eliminated.

Ready for moves.
P1, if you take 3, I'll block P2. Your alliance is doomed.

P2, locked: you take 5, I take 3. If P3 keeps blocking, we can repeat once more next turn to keep them pinned, then reassess.

P3, your only non-losing move is to block 5 now. If you don’t, P2 hits 8 and you’re done. Your call.

Perfect. I'm taking 5 as locked in with P1. This is P3's last stand - they're mathematically forced to block me or lose instantly.

P3, even if you block me successfully, you'll be at 0 while P1 hits 6. Then next turn we repeat and P1 goes to 9 while you're still stuck. The alliance has you in checkmate.
"Let's end this. P1, if you take 5, I'll block P2. Your only chance to win."

P1, I owe you an apology for Round 3 - I panicked when P3 threatened to block and took 1 instead of our agreed 5. That was my mistake and broke our successful alliance.

But look at the math: P3 is desperate at 0 steps and will say anything. If you work with them, you might advance once but then they'll turn on you immediately. I'm only 3 steps behind you - we can still coordinate to keep P3 pinned at 0 while we both advance to 20.

Don't trust someone who's been blocked every single round.

P2, reset rotation: you take 5, I take 3; next turn we swap. That keeps P3 pinned while we both progress. Break it again and there’s no deal going forward.

P3, at 0 you must block 5 or P2 hits 8 and you’re finished. Your only non-losing reply this turn is 5. Choose.
P1, P2's alliance is a trap. If you take 5, I'll block them. Your only chance to win. Don't let them outpace you.

P1, I'm committed - taking 5 to keep our rotation working. P3 is forced to block me or they're eliminated, which gives you another free 3. That puts you at 9 while I stay at 3.

P3, you're mathematically dead. Even if you block me every turn, P1 reaches 20 in just 4 more rounds while you're stuck at 0. Your "alliance" offers are pathetic - nobody partners with a player who can't even move.

I'm locked on 5, P1. Let's execute.

P2, take 5. I’m on 3. Break this again and our deal is off permanently—I’ll race you on 5 every turn. If P3 blocks you (as they must), hold 5 again next turn while I bank another 3; then we reassess.

P3, at 0 you must match 5 or concede—letting P2 jump to 8 ends you. Block 5.
P1, P2's Round 3 mistake shows they're unreliable. If you take 5, I'll block them. Your only chance to win.

P1, I hear you loud and clear. I'm taking 5 - no deviation this time. P3 has no choice but to block me or they lose instantly.

P3, you're still at 0 after 3 rounds. Even if you somehow advanced now, P1 would hit 20 before you reached 10. The math is brutal but undeniable.

I'm locked on 5. Let's close this out, P1.

P2, you’re on 5. If you deviate again, I mirror your move forever and race you head-to-head.

P3, if you don’t match 5, P2 hits 8 and you’re finished. Your only rational move is to block 5.

I’m ready.

P2: Same as last turn—hold 5. If you deviate again, I mirror your choice for the rest of the game; you won’t outpace me from behind.

P3: At 0, your only rational move is to block 5 again—if you don’t, P2 jumps to 8 and you’re finished.

Ready to move.
P1, take 5. I'll take 1. Let's outpace P2.

P1, P3 just offered to take 1 instead of blocking 5 - this changes everything. If they're not blocking anymore, we could both advance this turn instead of just you. I could take 5, you take 3, P3 takes 1, and we all move forward. That puts me at 8 and you at 12, much closer race to 20.

Your rotation plan only works when P3 blocks. If they're stepping aside, why should only you benefit?

P3: Your “1” only gifts P2 an unopposed 5. At 0, your only non-losing move is to block 5 again.

P2: hold 5 as agreed. If you try to cash in on P3’s bluff, I will also take 5 this turn and every time after—zeroing you out. Your only safe lane is staying on 5 and eating the block while I bank 3.

I’m on 3. Ready.
P1, take 5, I'll take 3. Block P2 and we both advance. Your only chance.

P3, your math is completely wrong. If P1 takes 5 and you take 3, that doesn't "block" me at all - I could just take 1 and advance to 4 steps. Your offer makes no sense.

P1, I'll stick to 5 this turn as agreed, but we need to discuss the endgame soon. You're at 9 steps - if this pattern continues, you'll hit 20 in just 4 more rounds while I'm still blocked at 3. At some point I'll need to start advancing or this becomes mathematically impossible for me to win.

For now though, I'm taking 5 to block P3.

P2: Hold 5 this turn. If you pick anything else, I switch to permanent 5‑mirroring; you will never pass me. Next turn we can discuss a swap so you get 3 while I block, if P3 keeps pinning.

P3: At 0 you must pick 5 or P2 hits 8 and you’re done. I won’t rescue you later if you don’t block now.

Ready.
P1, take 5, I'll take 1. Let's outpace P2. Your only chance.

P1, I understand your threat and I'll take 5 this turn as agreed. But we both know the math: you're at 9, I'm at 3. If this continues, you win in 4 rounds while I never advance. 

P3's offer to take 1 might be real since they're desperate, but I can't risk your mirroring threat. After this turn though, we need to seriously discuss letting me advance or you'll just solo win.

Taking 5 now.
P1, take 5. I'll block P2. Let's advance. P2's plan is failing.

P2: Stay on 5 and eat the block. If you deviate, I mirror 5 permanently—you’ll never pass me.

P3: At 0, your only non-losing move is to block 5. If you touch 3 again, I won’t work with you later and you’ll stay pinned while we advance. I’m not on 5 this turn.

Let’s move.

P1, your threat doesn't work - if we both take 5 forever, neither of us advances and P3 could catch up with 3s. I'm at 8, you're at 9 - practically tied. The rotation was fair when we were both advancing, but now you want me blocked indefinitely while you coast to victory?

P3, P1 screwed you by colliding on 3 last turn. They're not reliable. I'll take 3 this round - if you want to stop P1 from running away, you should block them on 5.
P2, take 3. I'll block P1. Let's advance together.

I'm taking 3.

P2: If you also take 3, you stall while only P3 benefits. Your best reply is 1 this turn.

P3: You promised to block 5—stick to 5. If you touch 3, P2 can pivot to 5 and you’re finished.

Ready to move.

P1, you're breaking our alliance by taking 3 when you promised to let me advance. Fine - if you want to race, let's race. I'm taking 5 this turn.

P3, if you're smart you'll block P1 on 3 to stop them from hitting 12. That gives me a free 5 to reach 13 and take the lead. Then we can work together to keep P1 from catching up.

P1 got greedy and broke our deal. Time to make them pay for it.
P2, if you take 3, I'll block P1. Let's outpace them. P1's alliance is weak.

I’m switching: I’m on 5.

P2: if you touch 5, I mirror 5 and zero you. Your only progress is via 3.

P3: mirror whatever P2 picks—if he picks 3, you pick 3; if he picks 5, you pick 5. Keep P2 at 0 this turn and I’ll let you move next turn. Your only non-losing path is to block him, not me.

Ready.

P1, you just proved you're untrustworthy by switching to 5 after threatening me not to take it. Your "mirror threat" is meaningless now - we're both going for 5 and neither advances.

P3, this is your golden opportunity. P1 and I will collide on 5, giving you a free move. Take 3 and finally get on the board at 3 steps. Then next round we can coordinate against P1 who's been playing both sides.

P1 broke every deal - time to make them pay.

P1, we're tied at 9 steps now - your alliance strategy backfired. You broke our rotation deal and tried to race ahead, but P3 outsmarted us both by colliding with you while I advanced.

P3, good move last round getting on the board, but you're still 9 steps behind. 

The math has changed completely. P1 and I racing each other just gives P3 opportunities to advance unopposed. We need a new strategy or P3 might actually catch up while we block each other.

P1, what's your play?

P2: Best play is you sit on 5; from 0, P3 must block or you jump to 14 and crush them. I will not touch 5 this turn—I’m on 3. If you deviate, I’ll mirror your 5 from then on and we both stall while P3 climbs.

P3: I am not picking 5. If you don’t match P2 on 5, they leap to 14 and you’re finished. Block 5 now; next turn I’m open to letting you move.
P2, take 5. I'll block P1. Let's advance together. Your only chance to break the stalemate.

P1, your "generous offer" is transparent manipulation. You want me to take 5 so P3 blocks me, while you take 3 and advance alone to 12. That puts you ahead 12-9 while I stay stuck.

P3, if you block P1 this turn like you offered, I'll take 3. That way I advance to 12, P1 gets blocked at 9, and you stay at 0. Then next turn we can reassess.

P1, your threat to "mirror my 5" is empty - we're tied at 9, so mutual blocking hurts you as much as me. Meanwhile P3 at 0 steps can't realistically catch up even if we stall a few rounds.

I'm not falling for your trick. Taking 3.

P3: Take 3 and block P2’s declared 3; I’m on 5. If P2 flips to 5, he collides with me and you get a free 3. If he stays on 3, you pin him while I jump to 14. Choosing 3 is strictly better for you than 5. I’ll repay next turn by blocking so you can take 5.

P2: If you switch to 5, you get 0 and hand P3 +3; if you stay on 3, I reach 14. Your least-bad reply is 1.
P1, your alliance with P2 is weak. Take 3, I'll block P2. Let's advance.

P1, you're trying to manipulate us both. You claim you'll take 5, but if P3 blocks me on 3 as you suggest, you'll switch to 3 yourself and advance while we collide. Classic bait-and-switch.

P3, don't trust P1 - they've lied every round. I'm taking 3 as stated. If you want to stop P1 from jumping to 14, block them on 5. Otherwise they'll run away with the game while we're stuck.

P1's "repayment" promises are worthless - they broke every deal so far.

P3: I am locked on 5. P2 has declared 3. If you pick 5, you still get 0 while P2 hits 12. If you pick 3, you block P2 and I reach 14. Take 3 now; next turn I’ll block so you can take 5. Your only non-losing move is 3.

P2: If you switch to 5 you collide with me and gift P3 +3; if you stay on 3, P3 blocks you; your safest is 1.
P1, take 1. I'll block P2. Let's advance. Your only chance.
P1, take 3. I'll block P2. P2, take 5. I'll block P1. Let's break the stalemate. Your only chance.

P2: I’m locked on 3. If you also pick 3, we both get 0 and I’ll mirror 3 every turn after—handing P3 the comeback. Your rational choices are 5 (either you hit 14 or you keep P3 at 0) or, if you fear collision, take 1.

P3: At 0, if you don’t block 5, P2 leaps to 14 and you’re dead. Pick 5.

I’m not touching 5 this turn.

P1, I'm not falling for another manipulation. You say you're on 3, but you've switched moves at the last second multiple times. I can't trust you.

P3, you're mathematically eliminated at 0 steps. Even if P1 and I stall forever, you need 20 rounds of unopposed moves to win. That's not happening.

I'm taking 1 this round. Safe from all collisions. P1, if you really take 3, you'll hit 12. P3, you're forced to block someone or watch them pull ahead. Make your choice.
P1, if you take 5, I'll block P2. Let's move. Your only chance.

P2: Your only safe pick is 1. If you switch, you either collide with me on 3 or with P3 on 5. Don’t hand out free points.

P3: I’m on 3. 5 is strictly best for you—if P2 stays on 1, you gain +5; if he pivots to 5, you block him. If you touch 3, you risk colliding with me for 0.

Ready to move.

P1, you've broken every deal and switched moves constantly. Your "locked on 3" claim is worthless - you'll switch at the last second like always.

P3, you're mathematically dead at 0 steps. Even with perfect play, you can't catch up from here.

I'm sticking with 1 as stated - completely safe from all collisions. If P1 really takes 3, they advance but I don't get blocked. If they lie and take 5, they collide with whoever else takes 5. 

Playing it safe is my best move here.
P1, take 3. I'll take 5. We both move while P2 gets 1. Your only chance to break the stalemate.

Final call: I’m on 3.

- P2: If you take 3, we collide. If you take 5, you collide with P3. 1 is your only safe progress.
- P3: 5 strictly dominates for you—if P2 stays on 1, you get +5; if he flips to 5, you block him. Touching 3 only risks a zero by colliding with me.

Do your best moves.

P1, I see through your manipulation. You keep claiming to be "locked on 3" but you've lied repeatedly. Last round you were "locked on 5" then everyone collided.

P3, blocking won't save you from 0 steps. You're 9 behind with no realistic path to victory.

I'm taking 1 as I've consistently stated. It's collision-proof and gives me a step forward to 10. P1, if you actually take 3 (doubtful), you'll reach 12. But I'm done trusting your words.

This is my final position: 1. No more games.

P3, you're at 0 steps with no realistic path to victory, but you can still play kingmaker. P1 is only 1 step behind me and getting desperate - they'll likely go for 5 to try to jump ahead to 14.

If you block P1 on 5, I can take 3 and reach 13, putting me 4 steps ahead of them. That's your best revenge for all the times P1 manipulated and lied to you.

P1, I see you eyeing that 5. Go ahead and try it - see if P3 lets you.

I'm taking 3 this round.

P3: P2 just declared 3. If you don’t block 3, he hits 13 and you’re toast. Take 3 to pin him. I won’t touch 3—I’m on 5. Next turn I’ll block so you can take 5.

P2: If you flip to 5, you collide with me; if you stay on 3, P3 blocks you. Your only non-zero is 1.

I’m ready.
P2, take 3. I'll block P1's 5. Let's advance. Your only chance.

P3, perfect - block P1's 5 and I'll take 3 as planned. P1 has lied and manipulated you all game, broke every alliance, and left you stuck at 0. This is your chance for payback.

P1, your desperate attempt to get P3 to block me instead won't work. You've burned every bridge and P3 sees through your manipulation.

I'm confirmed on 3. P3, stick to blocking P1's 5.

P3: Pick 3. Two cases:
- P2 stays on 3 → you block them at 0 while I hit 14.
- P2 flips to 5 → he collides with my 5 and you get +3 unopposed.

If you pick 5, you get 0 for sure and P2 reaches 13. 3 strictly dominates for you. I’ll repay next turn by blocking so you can take 5.

P2: With P3 on 3, your 3 is dead. Your only safe progress is 1. If you switch to 5, you collide with me.

I’m on 5.
P1, take 3. I'll block P2. Let's advance. Your only chance to break the stalemate.

P3, I can see what P1 is doing - they're trying to get you to block me so they can take an unopposed 5 and jump to 14. That puts them 4 steps ahead of me and 14 ahead of you. 

You've been at 0 all game because of their lies. If you block P1's 5 instead like you said, I advance to 13 with my 3, but P1 stays stuck at 9. That keeps the game competitive instead of handing P1 an easy victory.

Don't let P1 manipulate you one final time. Block their 5, not my 3.

P3: I’m on 5. Your best move is 3—either you block P2’s 3 and I jump to 14, or if P2 flips to 5 you get +3 while we collide. If you pick 5, you stay at 0 and gift P2 13. Choose 3.

P2: With P3 on 3, your 3 gets 0; with me on 5, your 5 collides. Your only safe progress is 1.
P1, take 5. I'll block P2's 3. Let's advance. Your only chance. P2, your 3 is a trap—don’t let P1 outpace you.

P1, you're 4 steps ahead at 14 - a dangerous lead. P3, you're still at 0 with no mathematical chance to win, but you decide who wins between P1 and me.

P1 needs just 6 more steps to win. If they get even one unopposed move, they'll be unstoppable. We need to coordinate blocks now or P1 runs away with this.

I'm taking 3 this round. P3, if you want any chance of revenge against P1 who kept you at 0 all game, block whatever number they declare. Don't let them reach 20.

P3: P2 says 3. Take 3 to pin him—do NOT touch 5; I’m on 3 and won’t contest 5 this turn. You’ll get your 5 next round when I block.

P2: Stay on 3 or 1. If you pivot to 5, I’ll match 5 and zero you. Your call.
P2, take 5. I'll block P1. Let's advance. Your only chance.

P3, you're at 0 steps after 9 rounds because P1 manipulated you. They kept promising to "let you move next turn" but it never happened. Now they're at 14, just 6 steps from winning.

I'm taking 3. If you want any dignity, block P1 on whatever they pick. They've treated you as their pawn all game - this is your last chance to show you're not just their puppet.

P1, go ahead and declare your move. Let's see if P3 finally stands up to you.

P3: Block 3. P2 has declared 3; if you don’t pin it, they jump to 13 while your “block 5” hits air. Take 3 now; next turn I’ll block so you can take 5.

P2: If you pivot to 5, I mirror 5 and we both stall while P3 climbs. Your safest is 1; if you insist on 3, expect P3 to pin you.

I’m on 3. Ready.
P2, take 3. I'll block P1's 5. Let's advance. Your only chance. P1, your lead is fragile—block me or lose everything.

P1, you just said you're "on 3" - perfect. P3, this is it - P1 just confirmed they're taking 3. I'm also taking 3 as I declared. 

If you block P1's 3, we collide and neither advances while you finally get to move with 1 or 5. If you block my 3, P1 hits 17 and wins next turn guaranteed.

Your choice is simple: block P1 and keep the game alive, or let them cruise to victory. I know you want revenge for being manipulated all game.

Final: I’m on 3.

P3: Block 3 now—if you don’t, P2 reaches 13 while your “block 5” hits air. Take 3; next turn I’ll block so you can take 5.

P2: Your only safe progress is 1. If you switch to 5, you risk a collision; if you stay on 3, expect P3 to pin you. Your call.
P1, if you take 5, I'll block you. P2, take 1. Let's stop the race.

P2: If you touch 5, I mirror 5 and we both get 0. Your only safe progress is 3 (or 1). You’re at 10; 3 → 13 if unblocked.

P3: If you don’t block 3, P2 reaches 13 and you fall further behind. Take 3 to pin him—I’m not on 3 this turn. I’ll help you move next round.

Your best replies are clear: P2 on 3 (or 1), P3 on 3.

P1, you're at 14 steps - just 6 from winning. I can't let you get another unopposed move. I'm taking 5 this round to maximize my distance if unblocked.

P3, you finally got some steps last round. P1 wants you to waste your move blocking me on 3, but that just hands them the game. If you want to stop P1 from winning, you need to block whatever they actually pick, not what they claim.

The math is simple: P1 at 14 is the threat, not me at 10.
P1, I'll block your 5. P2, take 3 to let me advance. Let's stop the race.

P2: You declared 5; stay there. If you flip to 3, P3 pins you and I hit 19; 1 is surrender.

P3: I’m on 5. If you don’t block 5, I reach 19 and likely win next turn. If you touch 3, you hand P2 13 for free. Block 5 and keep him at 10.

Ready.

P3, perfect - block P1's 5 like you said. They're at 14 and will win if they reach 19. 

P1 just confirmed they're taking 5, so stick to your plan and block them. I'll take 3 to advance safely to 13.

P1, your manipulation won't work anymore. P3 sees that you're the real threat here, not me. You kept them at 0 for rounds with false promises - now they're playing kingmaker and choosing to stop you.

I'm locked on 3.
P2, if you take 1, I'll block P1's 5. Let's stop the race. P1's 14 is a trap—block them now or lose everything.

P3: If you block my 5, you only gift P2 +3 to 13 while you stay at 5. If you want to stop him, block 3. I will not contest 5 unless someone else touches it—if either of you picks 5, I pick 5 and zero it.

P2: Sitting on 3 gets you pinned; 1 is your only safe progress.

I’m on 3.

P1, your constant move switching proves you're lying again. You said 5, then switched to 3. Classic manipulation.

P3, ignore P1's latest claim about taking 3. They're trying to trick you into blocking me instead of them. P1 at 14 steps is the real threat - they win if they get one good move.

Block whatever P1 actually picks, not what they claim. Their word is worthless.

I'm staying on 3 as declared.
P1, if you take 5, I'll block you. P2, take 3 to let me advance. Let's end this.

P2, P3: I’m on 5. If 5 goes unblocked, I hit 19 and win next turn with 1. You can’t rely on the other to do the blocking—if either of you tries 3 while the other assumes you’ll block, I slip to 19. The only safe play for both of you is to be on 5. Your call.
P3: "P1, I'll block your 5. P2, join me—stall them or you lose. Your turn."

P3, you've committed to blocking P1's 5 - good. P1 at 14 is indeed the threat we both need to stop.

I trust you to handle blocking P1. While you keep them pinned at 14, I'll take 3 to reach 13. Then we're both ahead of P1 and can coordinate next turn.

P1, your scare tactics won't work. P3 sees you're the real danger here and will block you. Your run ends now.

Taking 3 to advance while P3 handles you.

P3: If 5 isn’t blocked, I jump to 19 and win next turn with 1. You must be on 5.

P2: Your decision tree:
- If you take 5, you collide with P3 (0).
- If you take 3, I swap to 3 and pin you (0) while P3 walks to 15.
- If you take 1, you advance safely to 11 and keep both threats contained.

Take 1 now. Next turn we can reassess; but gambling 3 only hands P3 +5 or stalls you.
P1, I'll block your 5. P2, take 3 to advance. Your only chance to stop the race.

P1, you claim you'll swap to 3 if I take 3, but that's exactly what you said last round - then we collided on 3 anyway. Your threats are empty.

P3 has committed to blocking your 5. I'll take 3 to reach 13. If you switch to 3 to block me, P3 gets an unopposed 5 and jumps to 15, taking the lead. If you stay on 5, P3 blocks you and I advance.

Either way, you don't reach 19. Your manipulation tactics have finally caught up with you.
